issues.title: Privacy concerns for not so public IDs?
issues.author: aj-stein-nist
issues.body:
Not all identifiers have a simple security or privacy model where they can always be publicly shared. The current enumeration of identifiers do not include such an example, but they do exist. As discussed in Session II of the IETF 120 SPICE meeting, I had summarized how in US public healthcare the business identifier of sole proprietor for reimbursement in the Medicare and/or Medicaid system is a social security number for that individual. That must not be shared anywhere. For systems of record for that agency, this data was toxic and any leakage was an immediate incident. Details below.

https://www.cms.gov/Medicare/Provider-Enrollment-and-Certification/MedicareProviderSupEnroll/downloads/EnrollmentNPI.pdf

I am willing to help add to the draft and consider privacy considerations around this potentially.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I agree this needs to be addressed. In general I don't think we can prohibit representation as a GLUE ID of any identifiers that also may contain personal data, but the privacy considerations section definitely needs to address this.

comments.author: aj-stein-nist
comments.body: I am willing to pitch in and write something to that effect if you want me to. Let me now.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: that would be fantastic

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: Addressed by #15, closing

issues.title: Feedback from US General Services Administration?
issues.author: aj-stein-nist
issues.body: Has anyone considered presenting this to staff in the [US General Services Administration](), particularly those may be directly or indirectly involved with the design and maintenance of sam.gov data store and supporting systems, perhaps the [Technology Transformation Services](https://www.gsa.gov/about-us/organization/federal-acquisition-service/technology-transformation-services/tts-solutions) or [Office of Government-Wide Policy (OGP)](https://www.gsa.gov/about-us/organization/office-of-governmentwide-policy)? The latter have experience building systems and supporting policy for such macro-scale solutions, so it may be worth reaching out the scope, content, and registry of identifiers are more complete and vetted.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I agree that this feedback should be sought once the scheme is more complete.

comments.author: pamelatech
comments.body: Is SAM.gov a good example to put into the spec?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
> Is SAM.gov a good example to put into the spec?

I think in time we probably could, but for the initial set we should avoid country-specific authority schemes

issues.title: Country name considerations
issues.author: brentzundel
issues.body: We need to consider country codes for glue IDs, as referenced here: https://github.com/cabforum/smime/blob/main/SBR.md#a1-organizationidentifier

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
Pam and I talked today about this.
The Authority Identifier combined with the External Number should be a unique value.

It is assumed that corporate identification schemes already handle any necessary namespacing as part of the external number. In the event that collisions are possible within the set of possible external identifiers for a scheme, then further namespacing might be necessary at the glue id level. If so, it should be done on the authority identifier as part of the registration process. That is, the different namespaces would be considered either different schemes operated by the same authority, or the same scheme operated by different authorities. In either case a unique authority identifier would be necessary for each.

comments.author: pamelatech
comments.body: I believe we have addressed this concern with text in PR #17 -  closing as resolved

issues.title: IETF120 - Why is an IANA PEN not sufficient?
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Question #1 from IETF 120 - copied from session notes (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)

AJ Stein: Why are existing identifiers like IANA’s PENs not sufficient?
- Roy Williams: the scope of identifiers needs to cover a wide range of entities, including those without U.S. entities or computers. The scheme needs to allow flexibility worldwide.
AJ (Follow-up): If this requires registration with IANA, that might be a problem.
- The Glue ID aims to provide a flexible and widely applicable solution, recognizing different authorities and their specific needs.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
GLUE ID is a common representation of issued identifiers, it is not of itself an issued identifier.

We should include PEN identifier examples and make sure they are a registered in the GLUE ID Registry

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: Also, registration of the authority schemes shouldn't need to be done by the authorities themselves. Anyone who can point to the scheme and how to resolve could register it.

issues.title: IETF 120 - Scope of Enumerating Identifiers
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Question Taken from the notes of the IETF 120 Vancouver plenary (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)
AJ: What is the scope of enumerating different identifiers?
- Mike Prorock: Our system tracks over 200 million unique businesses, accounting for various identifiers required by different jurisdictions and regulatory purposes.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
We could add a section giving more detail about what an authority identifier means and discuss the scope of each identifier.

As far as the authority identifiers themselves, as many of them should be registered as folks need.

issues.title: IETF 120 - Privacy concerns with some identifiers
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Questions taken from IETF 120 Vancouver Plenary notes (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)

AJ: What about the privacy concerns associated with certain identifiers, such as taxpayer identifiers for sole proprietors?
(Brent Zundel) Please raise the issue for further discussion, we need to address this

comments.author: pamelatech
comments.body: Closing as a duplicate of [https://github.com/mesur-io/draft-zundel-spice-glue-id/issues/2](https://github.com/mesur-io/draft-zundel-spice-glue-id/issues/2)

comments.author: pamelatech
comments.body: Duplicate as noted above

issues.title: IETF 120 - Nested Organizations & Subsidiary Relationships
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Questions from IETF 120 Plenary in Vancouver (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)

AJ Stein: How does the system handle nested organizations and confidence in subsidiary relationships?
The draft describes a string identifier as a building block, with future layers handling more complex relationships and attestations.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
To me this points to the need for showing examples of how we imagine GLUE IDs could be used.
In a scenario where a subsidiary needs to be identified, then the authority identifier used in the GLUE ID needs to support identification of subsidiaries. Not all GLUE ID authority identifiers may support all circumstances.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: related to #14

issues.title: IETF 120 - Who can mint a Glue ID
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Questions from IETF 120 Plenary Vancouver (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)

AJ Stein: Can arbitrary organizations mint these identifiers?
The registry aims to include well-known organizations that identify businesses, but flexibility allows for new authorities to be recognized based on trust and context.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: We need to update the abstract to say that GLUE IDs are a representation format for existing issued identifiers.

issues.title: IETF 120 - Should Glue IDs be in SPICE?
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body:
Questions taken from IETF 120 Plenary Vancouver (https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-120-spice)

Heather Flanagan (chair) : How does this fit within SPICE?
The Glue ID provides a unified way to refer to companies, aligning with SPICE’s goal of managing credentials and attestations about entities.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
@pamelatech the introduction already has the text
```
Enterprise entity identifiers are myriad. With the increasing use of digitial
credentials, there is a need for a common methodology for expressing these
identifiers such that claims about and by such entities can be made in a
consistent and interoperable manner.
```

do we need more than this to strengthen the claim that the spec belongs in SPICE?

issues.title: bikeshed for "authority identifier scheme"
issues.author: brentzundel
issues.body: we could benefit from better words for "authority identifier scheme"

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I'm closing this, it's fine for now

issues.title: Registry structure question from David Dong
issues.author: brentzundel
issues.body: 1) Where should the new "’glue’ Scheme URI Authority Identifiers" registry be located? Should this be placed in an existing registry group, or should we create a new registry group, and if so, what should this new registry group be titled?

issues.title: Should a Glue ID have a fragment?
issues.author: pamelatech
issues.body: I believe that there is a need for businesses to be able to add additional local identifiers or data to a glue id.    As an example,  we might want to say the business identifier is Dunn & Bradstreet company 12345, factor 52B.  For companies with many global business identities and many factories (for example), it may be important to say that a given factory is identified relative to a given business identifier.  In this case for example do we want the glue id for a factory certified in France under the french business identifier 12345 as 52B to be "glue:dun.12345#52B".  The guidance here would be for anyone resolving to remove the fragment prior to validating/resolving the number at Dunn & Bradstreet.  I do not think the fragment needs to be technically resolveable, it may be that only the business owner knows what 52B means, or it is also possible that the company's factory identifiers are public and available for further lookup.   Note that some business authorities have this kind of granularity already built into the identifier, but there still may be internal context that businesses want to add.  The obvious downside is that should we decide a fragment is a good idea, it would make the identifiers longer.

pulls.title: Fix minor typo in URI scheme syntax header
pulls.author: aj-stein-nist
pulls.body: Looks good, so far, but it is hard to ignore once I saw it. 😄

pulls.title: Added URI Scheme Registration
pulls.author: pamelatech
pulls.body: Fixed author attribution and added a section based on RFC 6694 describing application for a new provisional URI scheme

pulls.title: Add privacy considerations around private IDs in glue URIs
pulls.author: brentzundel
pulls.body: This PR introduces a privacy considerations section, and adds a subsection for considerations when private identifiers are used in corporate identifiers.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: fixes #2

reviews.author: pamelatech
reviews.body: I added a suggestion of text that speaks directly to implementers, please take a look. Otherwise I think this clarifies the issue raised.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Implementers storing or evaluating glue ids are encouraged to evaluate the privacy characteristics of each authority potentially represented by authority identifiers and to appropriately handle any glue id whose authority identifier format violates privacy policies.
```

```suggestion
Implementers storing or evaluating glue ids are encouraged to evaluate the
privacy characteristics of each identification scheme represented by an authority
identifier and to appropriately handle any glue id which violates privacy policies.
```
